instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.SMC_DELAYED: What is SMC_DELAYED? SMC_DELAYED Is an abbreviation of SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD which is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU heats up, draws .35A
threads.message:
Came in from another shop.  Liquid damage was cleaned on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. Replaced chip, repaired 3.42 supply trace.

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> seems good:
   1. <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.3
   2. <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>: 3.3
   3. <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL>: 3.4
   4. GND
   5. <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>: 3.3
   6. <SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED</SIGNAL> : 3.4
   7. <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>: 3.3
   8. 3.4 present

Problem is no display or boot.  No USB activity that I can see.
I get fanspin, no chime
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> : 3.3
<SIGNAL>VCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> stays at 1.8
1V05 present for PCH
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL> : 0 (known good screen attached)
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> : 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU heats up, draws .35A
threads.message:
No reason to search for image, if no USB activity at least.
Do you get <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

Possibly accumulated crap underneatch PCH/CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU heats up, draws .35A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 0

As an aside:  Would it be OK to use my hot air station with a large nozzle or should I only use oven to reflow cpu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU heats up, draws .35A
threads.message:
My issues seem to mirror this person's: [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-powers-on-but-no-usb-activity-and-no-post.60774/#post-71615[/URL]

Including the power off when I measure <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL>.  If I measure this between reboot cycles I can get a reading without it powering off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU heats up, draws .35A
threads.message:
lol so i got impatient, and tomorrow's the day i'm supposed to tell the customer if it's fixable or not.  

reflowed the CPU at around 350c, with a lake of flux and full airflow.  I paid attention to the CPU pcb mostly, kept away from the CPU die itself but did hit the pch die area after i felt like the sides were good not for too long mind.  It boots, but is missing backlight.  I'll fix that in a jif.

I LOVE YOU 2INFORMATICOS, YOU ARE 2GOOD 2US.
